subject: Re: I'd like to be able to write the prefixes com- and con- as contractions
msgSnippet: Thanks, Sid. The reason why I didn t use this work-around is because I ve been trying to follow the QuikScript rule that the letters represent sounds of the
messageBody:
Thanks, Sid.

The reason why I didn't use this work-around is because I've been trying to follow the QuikScript rule that the letters represent sounds of the English language.

In com- con- the o sound is like the u in utter (as in commend, contend), or like the o in ox (compliment, conscious). The o when written as in Latin letters (as a circle) has the sound of owe in owe. Therefore com- with the circle o would rhyme with comb, and con- with the circle o would rhyme with cone, which is not what I want to.

However, if I were making notes for myself, as is the case most of the time I use QuikScript, I could certainly use the o as a private work-around.

What I have been using as an even shorter work-around for temporary private notes (to-do list, notes of a meeting discussion to be transcribed fairly soon on the computer) is just the k as a prefix, thus kputer for computer, kshus for conscious, etc.


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Sid Tanaban <sidban2@...> wrote:
>
> com or con can be written in one stroke. Â Just write the "o" as you would in latin letters and add the "m" Â  Unfortunately, I have no idea how to do this on a computer.
> Sid
>

> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "steveb_667" sbartok1632@
>
> wrote:
>
> >
>
> > Page #21 of Kingsley Read manual details a partial solution to your
>
> question. For words where "com-" and "con-" are not stressed, the "o" is
>
> omitted. This makes "km-" and "kn-," which are very easy to write
>
> longhand.
>
> >
>
> > Once a "com-" or "con-" are stressed, though, the "o" should be
>
> written out. There is no 'easy' way to write "com-" and "con-" in one
>
> pen stroke, if this is what you are implying. Quikscript is
>
> semi-cursive, not completely cursive. Page #13 of the manual emphasizes
>
> this point.
>
> >
>
> > --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "cossyrosario" cossyrosario@
>
> wrote:
>
> > >
>

>
> all

> > > 40+ characters, learned joined letters like ar, or, etc.,
>
> contractions
>
> > > for words, suffixes and prefixes.
>
> > >
>
> > > I'd like to understand how to write the prefixes com- and con- which
>
> are
>
> > > found in innumerable words in the English language. Writing k and o
>
> > > together is troublesome enough, but adding the third letter is the
>
> hard
>
> > > part. Most of the other prefixes and suffixes can be written with
>
> > > characters joined to form one combined character easy to write and
>
> > > readily recognizable. Is there a simplified way of writing com- ?
>
> Would
>
> > > it be acceptable to use just k- with the hyphen to represent both
>
> com-
>
> > > and con- as contraction for the full prefix?
>
